body:
Interestingly, I've just noticed that if I remove everything from the localisation files apart from the line `Quick_Game=Быстрая Игра` then it translates correctly.

Also, if I change the line to `Quick_Game=1Быстрая Игра` (added a 1 at the start) then in outputs

```
1Быстрая гра
```

So the И disappears.
Please provide a [SSCCE](http://sscce.org/)

@davebaol Due to the fact that bitmap font and localisation files are required I can't create a copy paste job. I don't think I can make it much more simple than the [github](https://github.com/WillCalderwood/localisation-test) project I provided.

If there's something you think I can do to improve on this then please let me know.

Doh I missed the github project before. 

Anyways looks like a weird issue and unfortunately I can't test it right now. 
Does [this log](https://github.com/WillCalderwood/localisation-test/blob/master/core/src/com/mygdx/game/MyGdxGame.java#L32) always show the same (wrong) string that you see on the screen?
Maybe you have to tell the browser what's the expected encoding.
Or you have to set the content type on the server.
BTW can you reproduce this issue in `I18NSimpleMessageTest` ?

> String created by br.readLine() is incorrect, so it looks to me like the UTF-8 decoding in BufferedReader is buggy. This seems like a fairly critical bug to exist in GWT however, so am I misunderstanding something?

Just realized that [BufferedReader](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/backends/gdx-backends-gwt/src/com/badlogic/gdx/backends/gwt/emu/java/io/BufferedReader.java) is emulated on GWT. 
The same goes for `Reader` and `InputStreamReader` classes.
And looks like `InputStreamReader` emulation ignores the encoding, see https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/backends/gdx-backends-gwt/src/com/badlogic/gdx/backends/gwt/emu/java/io/InputStreamReader.java#L22

I'd say this is a libgdx issue. Not sure though.

It does indeed, but look at [this](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/backends/gdx-backends-gwt/src/com/badlogic/gdx/backends/gwt/emu/java/io/InputStreamReader.java#L37). It would appear to default to UTF-8, so this shouldn't be a problem in this instance.

I'm assuming that line is decoding from UTF-8 to UTF-16 to store the char array in memory.

I can reproduce your issue in `I18NSimpleMessageTest` which has been slightly modified in order to use the "ru" locale. 
I suptect this is a bug in `BufferedReader` emu. With default buffer size of 32 I get a wrong character in every 16, almost always. By increasing the size to 1024 the issue apparently disappears.
Maybe something related to line endings and/or `fill()` invocation. Just guessing though.

Looks like there's no easy way to work around this with the current version of LibGDX then? I created [this](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/31986025/why-does-this-text-decoded-in-2-different-ways-not-match-in-gwt) question on StackOverflow too to see if someone has anything else to add to this.
The BufferedReader in Android has a default buffer size of 8192, which seems reasonable, 32 seems rather low.

Yeah but this won't fix the issue.

BTW just tested with size 16 and 8. Wrong characters appear more frequently, respectively in almost every 8 and 4 characters.
Basically, the lower the buffer size the higher the frequency of wrong characters.

UTF8 chars have variable length. Maybe long chars that are overlapping the buffer size (thus `fill()` is called in between) are not managed properly. Again, just speculating :)

Whether it fixes the issue or not, we should make a more sensible default
than 32, which pretty well makes buffering pointless.
On Aug 13, 2015 6:27 AM, "davebaol" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Yeah but this won't fix the issue.
> 
> BTW just tested with size 16 and 8. Wrong characters appears more
> frequently, respectively in almost every 8 and 4 characters.
> Basically, the lower the buffer size the higher the frequency of wrong
> characters.
> 
> UTF8 chars have variable length. Maybe long chars that are overlapping the
> buffer size (thus fill() is called in between) are not managed properly.
> Again, just speculating :)
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/issues/3350#issuecomment-130670272.
Sure, I'm not against :)

Ok I think the problem is not in `BufferedReader` but rather in `InputStreamReader`.
If I got it right, its `read` method decodes the buffer using `Utf8.decode16` which has no memory. This means that uncompleted characters at the end of the buffer are wrong.

I might be missing something, but it looks like that method does no bounds checking at all, it simply assumes that all data is available for each entire character (e.g. [this code](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/backends/gdx-backends-gwt/src/com/badlogic/gdx/backends/gwt/emu/avian/Utf8.java#L67-L68)). In that case I'd expect an index out of bounds exception to be thrown (not sure how gwt deals with that though).

Yeah I'd expect that exception too, but for some reason it never happened in my tests. Just corrupted characters.
Anyways, partial characters occurring at the end of the buffer are not managed properly.
If you look at Android or JDK implementation you can clearly see that the decoder has some kind of memory.

rename.from: Cyrillic localisation not returning the correct text in GWT
rename.to: GWT: utf-8 characters at the end of the buffer can be corrupted by BufferedReader
